author: samwilsn
content:
<@!683653554631868440> the gist of what I was saying is that regardless of what the specification is written in, there will be a step for the reader to translate from the document to "the concepts the spec describes" then from that into the client code.

Math notation is much cleaner in the first step, because it doesn't influence the algorithms or require any python knowledge. On the other hand, I think--for the target audience of developers--Python will be easier, even though the first translation step also involves removing the Python-specific crud.

author: samwilsn
content: You think people will notice the file name being different? I thought it was subtle enough to be acceptable.

author: samwilsn
content: Hm, I guess we could catalog all of the joke PRs that have existed so far, then stop the tradition going forwards, but I _like_ April Fools'

author: samwilsn
content:
We've been talking a lot about adding more features to the EIP bot. I've opened an issue to track and discuss fields we'd like the EIP bot to handle:

https://github.com/ethereum/EIP-Bot/issues/61

author: gcolvin
content:
It's all of them having the same EIP number that is suspicious, and (if I understood) having them not be ordinary PRs.  Some of the April 1 EIPs were obvious jokes, like the Drink Menu and the Number of the Beast.  But I actually got a little ways into <@403707149043105803> 's  DEST Operation before I was sure it was a joke.

And I like April 1 PRs too, but I'd bet good ETH that  Micah would not agree. And this wasn't just any April Fools Day -- it was also All Core Devs day.

author: _shemnon
content: That was the ideal outcome.  Which is why I made it clear in security considerations.
